displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: We’re also starting a study probably not for a few months yet though. We’ve had two patients now who got testosterone. They both responded to testosterone but we then put them on something for the immune therapies, just not a trial, just hit or miss. And both of those two patients had incredible response to immune therapy. Patient: Hum. Doctor: So they started like negative something, so we’re going to try a trial where we are going to prime the cancer. Not actually treat it just to get the cancer you know. We think the testosterone potentially changes the cancer, the DNA of the cancer, and maybe that makes the cancer more recognizable by the immune system. So that’s- Patient: so it would somebody who just had the- Doctor: The trial is to get testosterone for three doses and then get immune therapy. Family Member: Well you couldn’t just do that as, like say you try it on those two guys, don’t you just try that with B__, knowing that there is still Germany, but um-? Doctor: Possibly. I have to figure how to get the immune therapy because it’s not an improved thing. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So there’s just some hoops to jump through. Family Member: Well, we’re kind of there now. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Like we really want to be treating this aggressively.

Family Member 1: See my daughter thought it was a placebo. I hope she doesn't Doctor: No and you know that at this stage of your cancer, you should never be on a placebo only trial that's actually unethical. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: So it should always be like, whatever is the standard, maybe it's a chemo, maybe it's a pill, but we do a lot of combo therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So one might be like, “Well, okay, you get chemo, you get chemo, but you'll get the extra pill and you'll get the placebo extra pill.” We don't know who's who but everyone gets chemo. So at the root of it, if everybody gets chemo, you're getting treatment and you're just trying to see if the extra thing does anything. Patient: I see. Doctor: So but it can never be like you get the pill and you get the placebo Pill that can't ever happen. That's just not ethical. And the IRB and all of our regulatory people would literally have spazz attack and we would never do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 3: Okay. Doctor: So just to put that at ease. You know, it's- there's a lot of myths going around. And some of it is founded in just the confusion, you know, like, we’ve gotten so complicated on how we do things now. And sometimes the description of that explanation isn't as maybe as thorough or you just, you know, I may say it, but you didn't really receive it. So there's a lot of that and the more complicated we get with our treatments, the worse that occurs. And to tell you the truth, part of the things that we always try to study and why you guys are graciously signed up is, you know, I may say something go, “No, no, no, I reviewed that with them.” And you guys are like, “Oh, honey, I've never heard it.” So we want to make sure whatever we're doing actually could be optimized, because it is complicated. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill?

Patient: God is gonna make sure the insurance is taken care of – Doctor: Mm, hmm. PAT - because your wasn’t for sure about the Provenge being taken care of… Patient: …and that was like what a hundred grand. Doctor: That was a hundred grand, yeah. Patient: And so and so the insurance took it right off. Doctor: Yep. Patient: We didn’t have to go to nobody. Doctor: We’re gonna make you the six million dollar man. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, and so yeah, and so and so this is gonna pass too. Doctor: Yes. We again, we’re just being really on top of it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So let me ask you this here because we talked about this in case it didn’t work.

Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now. Doctor: Yeah Patient: But the quality of life has been reasonably good. Doctor: That’s- Yeah. That’s that’s the best part to hear. Absolutely. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Good. Patient: So I mean it’s just um and then I had um breakfast with this guy who is a couple years ahead of me in high school and he…

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right.

Patient: Don’t hesitate to Doctor: Yeah. Oh, I know, I know, I know. I know, I know. Patient: I mean --- Family Member: So Patient: I understand some people Doctor: And, you know, that’s a test also they could just do on their own. They can go to web site and order the test. Patient: Right, right, exactly. Doctor: They don’t need a doctor to do it. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, huh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So.

Patient: I - at this point I think you all are taking pretty good care of me. So that means a lot to me and so, but I will touch base with him. Family Member: So this, I know it’s not cure. But you mentioned, you said remission a couple of times. What constitutes remission when you’re speaking of cancer? Doctor: Remission means that the cancer disappears completely. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Or partially. So the complete remission would mean that the PSA level goes to zero. Family Member: Is that something that could possibly happen in this case? Doctor: With the hormone therapy—yes. Family Member: With the hormone therapy—yes. Doctor: It happens frequently. Now it’s a bit misleading because it’s not truly zero. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s below the limit of detection, so the laboratory for example is below zero point one milligrams per ml. Family Member: Uh hum.

Family Member: Xtandi, okay. Doctor: and then we’ll throw on a second medication. Patient: What are the names of the other two drugs? Doctor: No names. All letters and numbers. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Poof! You just turn into a guinea pig again. You were there before, but yeah. I think that’s the hard part. It’s umm, you know, they don’t give names unless it’s moving along the path of development. Umm. And then uh, it’s sorta like you don’t name your pet…you don’t think you’re gonna keep it. I don’t know. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: But, it’s usually letters and numbers. Ummm. But, they work in a class of drugs that we think are highly active in prostate cancer, so it’s about five different drugs that are in this space, targeting the same pathway. So, we just don’t know which one has an opening. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And, when would that start? Doctor: M___ will tell us, but probably, you know, obviously in the new year, and it maybe second or third week… Patient: Well, they took seven vials of blood…

Family Member: No, no, no, we're going to get pizza. Doctor: Why is your PSA 10?! Patient: I don’t know! Doctor: Let me whine some more. What the hell? Are you taking your pills? Patient: Mhmm. Religiously. Doctor: Are you taking four or are you taking three? Patient: Four. Doctor: Argh! I can’t even trip him off. Family Member: I know. I know. Doctor: Well… you might need chemo. Let me say that again. You might need chemo. Was that whiney enough for you? Family Member: Yeah. Well, at least you have something. You could’ve came in here and said, “Oh, we got nothing for you. Doctor: Oh no, I got tons of stuff for you. The question is when and how and how do you feel about that. Family Member: S___?

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Those are the seminal vessels. (Pause 10 seconds) Family Member: And this, we were just surprised because there’s nothing that would indicate all that. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: His PSA being low, and the prostate not being enlarged, and the preliminary report they told us we thought when you called down that day we were here. Doctor: I know. I’m really upset by passing incorrect information to you based on the verbal report. That’s the danger of doing that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. I’m like what were you looking at? The other sixteen lymph nodes first? (Laughs) Patient: We’re hoping you got the samples switched or something like that. Doctor: You know I was actually gonna check that and I haven’t done that. The big question is did anybody else have prostate surgery on the same day. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm, hmm. Doctor: Not by me, but it could be another doctor. Family Member: I would like to check it just for peace of mind only, but there’s nothing that would lead us to think it was all this and to be fifty to sixty percent involved with the prostate kind of blew our minds a little bit. Doctor: Me too. Yeah.

Patient: No, that one over there, I didn’t. That’s why I told them I didn’t want to come back over there no more. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I didn’t… they didn’t impress me. I mean, they fine (laughs) Doctor: Don’t tell me. They didn’t yell at you enough? Doctor: Okay. Patient: It’s south for you and I’m gonna start going there. Doctor: Okay, but I’ll send it in because I don’t want you to run around with high blood pressure either. Patient: Right. Doctor: Especially, when we are starting you on a medicine that could Patient: Right, can Doctor: Worsen your blood pressure. I may need to adjust it further. Patient: Okay. How about like walking for extended, like, two to three mile walks, is that, is that alright? Doctor: It’s play it by ear as to how much you are hurting.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Uh good. Doctor: What’s going on otherwise? Patient: Not much. Doctor: Job? Patient: It’s much better. Doctor: Last time you Patient: I think so, yeah. It’s still a little bit, it’s real tiny. It feels better than it did four weeks ago. Doctor: And the last time you had some seepage in your lower lung and you’re still a little tiny Patient: Yes. Doctor: That’s Last week and – And how Patient: I guess I need to keep putting the ointment on, you know. Doctor: And how’s your appetite? Patient: Good.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You have Provenge. Um, so um, the one standard thing that’s left is a radiation-based thing but that’s really only for disease of the bone. You have lymph node as well. So I would sort of not use that. The other thing that’s left is chemotherapy, flavors, uh so that’s something we could always go to. The other sort of unfortunately gray zone (beeping) Patient: Sure. Doctor: Uh and some of that’s clinical trial. A lot of the clinical trials we have right now are hormonal based. So it’s Zytiga plus something, Xtandi plus something. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Versus something. So unfortunately uh you wouldn’t fit all those trials because of the prior treatments we have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication.

Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. Hhh (chuckles) Family Member: So, until Doctor: So, I’ll, I’ll start that. You’re gonna need to sign a permission and all that with T_. Healthcare Professional: Yep. Doctor: And, she’ll go over all the, the, the other detail, which you’ve already read. You know, this is the opportunity for you to ask me questions and see if there is any reason that you want to abort, uh, or say this is the right way to go. Uh, and, then, I’ll get your medicines written and plan for your hormone shot in two weeks. And, then, we can leave it a little bit up in the air between T_, myself, as to what, uh day per our calendar when you wanna just say, “Okay, this is…” Patient: Well, well, well, we’ll work within that, that four-week window of the month. That has to start with - I just, again, if we, if the advice was to start same day, I would. If you wait four weeks, we will pick a date four weeks out and start then. Doctor: Yeah, and if he had a little bit more flexibility, just again, if we started then, and it ends up on Christmas and the holidays. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um -
